ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Cochlear pathology
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Despite red flags (WRS decline, reflex decay), ABR and CT results ruled out retrocochlear lesions, suggesting the decline is cochlear in nature.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Retrocochlear pathology
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Initially suspected due to significant asymmetric decline in word recognition scores and abnormal acoustic reflex decay, but subsequently ruled out.

ordered_list.rationale_short: Standard assessment of hearing sensitivity and monitoring of thresholds over time.
To assess word recognition abilities and determine if changes are statistically significant using critical difference tables.
Investigated due to the significant decline in word recognition to screen for retrocochlear pathology.
Ordered by the otologist to rule out central/retrocochlear findings after abnormal reflex decay and WRS decline were noted.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Baseline evaluation revealed bilateral asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss, worse in the right ear in the high frequencies. Speech recognition thresholds were consistent with pure-tone averages, and word recognition scores were excellent bilaterally.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Normal limits 250-2000 Hz bilaterally; Right moderate to moderate-severe SNHL 3-8 kHz; Left mild to moderate-severe SNHL 3-8 kHz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRTs 10 dB HL bilaterally; WRS 88% Right and 98% Left.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Annual monitoring visit. Word recognition scores showed a slight reduction from baseline but were considered stable compared to the previous year (2010) and did not meet criteria for significant change.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: WRS 80% Right and 82% Left; essentially unchanged from previous year.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Evaluation revealed a significant decline in the right ear. While pure-tone thresholds showed only a 10 dB drop at specific frequencies, the Right WRS dropped significantly (from 80% to 40%). Acoustic reflex decay was positive in the right ear. These findings prompted a referral to an otologist and subsequent ABR/CT, which ruled out retrocochlear pathology.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear thresholds decreased by 10 dB at 250 Hz and 3000-4000 Hz compared to previous; Left ear stable.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right WRS 40% (significant decline from 80%); Left WRS 70% (not a significant decline from 82%).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Contralateral reflexes absent/elevated bilaterally; Ipsilateral absent Right 500-4000 Hz; Abnormal reflex decay Right at 1000 Hz.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.result_summary: Delayed Wave V latencies bilaterally; Absent Wave I and II Right; No strong indication of central dysfunction.

proposed_items: Reprogramming of right hearing aid to accommodate threshold changes
Referral to otologist for medical investigation of asymmetry and reflex decay
counseling_actions: Counseling on the statistical significance of the word recognition score decline using critical difference tables
Explanation of ABR and CT results ruling out retrocochlear pathology
Counseling on the benefits of Hearing Assistive Technology
Discussion regarding potential benefits of cochlear implantation

red_flags_present: Significant asymmetric decline in word recognition scores

escalation.rationale_short: Referral warranted due to significant change in hearing (WRS decline) and abnormal reflex decay to rule out retrocochlear pathology.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor thresholds and word recognition scores for any further changes.

expected_outcome: Right hearing aid was reprogrammed to accommodate the 10 dB decrease in hearing at 3000-4000 Hz.
Patient stated that his word recognition improved slightly following the hearing aid adjustment.
Patient continues to see otologist to manage right ear canal swelling.
Patient expressed a lack of interest in cochlear implantation despite conversation about possible benefits.
Recommendation for Hearing Assistive Technology has not yet been followed by the patient.
